title: How to Determine the Current Value of Your Fix-and-Flip Properties
excerpt: Accurately estimating your property's value is essential for fix-and-flip success. Learn the best methods for valuing your investment, whether you're prepping for a resale, refinancing, or analyzing your next deal.

content.text: Why Property Value Matters for Fix-and-Flip Investors

Knowing the up-to-date value of your flip is key for setting your ARV (After Repair Value), negotiating purchases, securing financing, and maximizing your ROI. It also helps ensure you have the right insurance, fair property tax assessments, and a solid exit strategy.

items: Market Approach: Compare your property to recent sales of similar homes (comps) in your area. This is the most common method for flips and gives you a realistic resale price.
Income Approach: Used less often in flipping, but helpful if you’re considering holding as a rental. Calculate the value based on rental income and local cap rates.
Cost Approach: Estimate what it would cost to rebuild the property, then subtract depreciation. Useful for unique properties or new construction flips.

content.text: How to Use the Market Approach for Your Flip

items: Find 3-5 recently sold comps similar in size, location, and condition (ideally within the last 3-6 months). Use MLS data, Redfin, Zillow, or Realtor.com.
Adjust comp prices for differences (e.g., garage size, pool, upgrades). Local market knowledge is crucial here.
Calculate the price per square foot for each comp, average them, and multiply by your property’s square footage to estimate value.
Ask a Local Agent for a CMA: Many agents offer free Comparative Market Analyses to win your business. Great for informal ARV estimates.
Order a Broker’s Opinion of Value (BOV): For a fee, brokers provide a detailed report—helpful for larger or more complex flips.
Hire a Licensed Appraiser: Needed for formal valuations, especially if you’re refinancing or disputing tax assessments. Lenders often require this for cash-out refis.

content.text: Maximize Your Profits with Accurate Valuations

Accurate property values mean smarter offers, better financing terms, and bigger profits when you sell. Whether you’re running your own comps or hiring a pro, know your numbers before you buy, renovate, or list your next flip.
